metadata.feature_description: Process and render Markdown content in wiki articles

steps.action: Navigate to Wiki module and click Create article
steps.expected: Article creation dialog opens with content editor
steps.actual: Dialog opened with WYSIWYG Redactor editor - no Markdown mode toggle visible

steps.action: Enter standard Markdown syntax including headers, bold, italic, lists, links, code blocks, and tables
steps.expected: Markdown syntax to be recognized and rendered
steps.actual: Content entered in HTML mode shows raw Markdown syntax as plain text

steps.action: Switch to visual mode to see rendering
steps.expected: Markdown content to be rendered (headers, bold, lists, etc.)
steps.actual: All Markdown syntax displayed as plain text - NO rendering occurred

steps.action: Publish article and view rendered output
steps.expected: Published article should show rendered Markdown
steps.actual: Published article displays all Markdown syntax as plain text. Exception: Wiki-style link [[Article]] was converted to clickable link

issues: Standard Markdown syntax (headers, bold, italic, lists, links, code blocks, tables) is NOT processed - displayed as plain text
No Markdown mode or toggle exists in the editor UI
The feature as described does not exist in the codebase

steps.action: Enter # Header 1 Test and ## Header 2 Test in article content
steps.expected: Headers should render as H1 and H2 HTML elements
steps.actual: Text '# Header 1 Test' and '## Header 2 Test' displayed as literal plain text

issues: Markdown header syntax (#, ##, ###) is not processed

steps.action: Enter - Item 1, - Item 2, - Item 3 in article content
steps.expected: Content should render as HTML unordered list
steps.actual: Text '- Item 1', '- Item 2', '- Item 3' displayed as literal plain text paragraphs

issues: Markdown list syntax (- or *) is not processed

steps.expected: Content should render as clickable HTML hyperlink
steps.actual: Text '[Click here](http://example.com)' displayed as literal plain text

issues: Standard Markdown link syntax [text](url) is not processed

steps.action: Examined editor toolbar for Markdown image syntax support
steps.expected: Ability to use ![alt](url) Markdown image syntax
steps.actual: Editor only supports inserting images via toolbar button (HTML). No Markdown image syntax processing exists

issues: Markdown image syntax ![alt](url) is not supported - only HTML images via editor toolbar

steps.action: Enter code block with triple backticks (```) containing JavaScript function
steps.expected: Content should render as formatted code block
steps.actual: Triple backticks and code content displayed as literal plain text

issues: Markdown code block syntax (```) is not processed

steps.action: Enter Markdown table with | Column 1 | Column 2 | syntax
steps.expected: Content should render as HTML table
steps.actual: Table syntax displayed as literal plain text lines

issues: Markdown table syntax (| pipes and dashes) is not processed

steps.action: Enter Wiki-style link [[TOC Test Article - Claude Testing]] in article content
steps.expected: Wiki-style link should be converted to clickable HTML link
steps.actual: Wiki-style link was successfully converted to a clickable hyperlink pointing to the referenced article

observations: CRITICAL: The 'Markdown Support' feature as described in the test specification does NOT exist. The Wiki module does NOT process standard Markdown syntax (CommonMark).
Code review revealed that the MarkdownProcessor.cs file only handles Wiki-style internal links: [[Subject]] and [[Title|Subject]] - NOT standard Markdown syntax.
The Wiki module uses a WYSIWYG Redactor editor that outputs HTML, not Markdown. There is no Markdown editing mode or toggle.
The only 'Markdown' processing that works is Wiki-style internal links [[ArticleTitle]] which get converted to HTML anchor tags linking to other wiki articles.
Standard Markdown features (headers with #, bold with **, lists with -, code blocks with ```, tables with |, links with [text](url)) are NOT supported and display as plain text.
The feature description 'Process and render Markdown content in wiki articles' is misleading - this capability does not exist in the current implementation.
